Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• Indicate how continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• Be signed and dated.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code 722.120 Investigation, inspection, and examination of
Title conditions, books, records, and reports; access by
department, bureau of fire services, or local authorities;
records; report; forms; confidentiality; disclosure of
information; availability of confidential records; child
information cards to be provided to department; failure of
licensee to cooperate with investigation, inspection, or
examination.
Rule Code & (1) The department may investigate, inspect, and examine
Section conditions of a child care organization and may investigate and
Description examine the licensee's books and records. The licensee must
cooperate with the department's investigation, inspection, and
examination by doing all of the following:
(c) Providing accurate and truthful information to the
department, and encouraging witnesses, such as staff and
household members, to provide accurate and truthful
information to the department.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff are coached to lie to investigators.
Investigation Chief Administrator 1 was interviewed on 01/30/2024 during an
unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. She stated she has
never said anything to staff or youth in the program that could be
construed as “coaching.” Chief Administrator 1 denied ever telling
staff or youth what to say when being interviewed by Licensing,
DHHS staff or Law enforcement.
Staff 1, Staff 2, Staff 3, Supervisor 1 and Chief Administrator 2
were all interviewed separately either over the phone or during
face-to-face visits to the facility. They all denied participating in
2

conversations with Chief Administrator 1 where they were
“coached” or were told what to say during interviews. No staff
stated they had heard Chief Administrator 1 “coach” any youth in a
similar manner.
Youth A was interviewed on 02/29/2024 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She stated she was “coached” by
Chief Administrator 1 on one specific occasion. Youth A could not
recall the exact date, but she did remember that this Licensing
consultant was visiting the facility on the same date this occurred.
It was confirmed this was on 01/30/2024. Youth A recalled this
specifically because she had only been placed in the program for
a few days and hadn't been able to go to school yet because of
some paperwork issues. Youth A stated the Licensee Designee
went upstairs to meet with the Licensing consultant, leaving her
downstairs in the dining area with Chief Administrator 1. Youth A
recalled Chief Administrator 1 stating to her there would be times
that Licensing or other DHHS staff would visit the program, and
they might ask her some questions. Chief Administrator 1 stated
“You need to make sure you don’t say anything that might get this
place shut down” to Youth A. Youth A also recalled Chief
Administrator 1 stating “Don’t say anything that’d get me in
trouble.” Youth A stated she never heard Chief Administrator 1
say anything similar to any other youth or staff in the program.
During Youth A’s interview she provided articulate and credible
details of this interaction.
Youth B was interviewed on 02/29/2024 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She denied ever hearing Chief
Administrator 1 say anything to any staff or youth that felt like they
were being “coached” on how to interview for investigations.
During a video conference on 02/26/2024 DHHS Worker 1 stated
that their investigation would not produce any findings.
Documentation reviewed:
• Attempts to review video footage were made through an
email request on 03/04/2024 and a previously announced
visit on 03/07/2024. Security footage that would have
captured the interaction between Youth A and Chief
Administrator 1 on 01/30/2024 was not available. It was
confirmed by the Licensee Designee through email on
03/12/2024 that the facility’s security camera system has a
30 day storage limit.
3

Analysis Through interviews with youth, there was evidence found that
Chief Administrator 1 instructed a youth to obstruct or lie to
investigatory staff.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code Privacy and confidentiality.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4130
Section (1) An institution shall assure resident and parent privacy and
Description confidentiality and shall protect residents from exploitation.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth are being watched while changing and being recorded
without their consent.
Investigation The Licensee Designee was interviewed during an
unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility on 01/30/2024. She
stated she was aware of an incident in late December 2023 where
Staff 1 and Staff 2 were attempting to verbally de-escalate youth,
and during this incident youth pulled the electrical plugs on several
security cameras. The Licensee Designee stated she was aware
Staff 1 had used his personal phone to record the youth during
this incident. She recalled discussing this with Staff 1, receiving
the footage from him and asking him to delete it from his own
property. The Licensee Designee confirmed there was no facility
policy on what to do if security cameras were not operational
during incidents.
Staff 1 was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
02/14/2024. Staff 1 recalled the incident in question as occurring
in late December. He stated the youth in the program were
having a “hissy fit” and all of them were escalated at the same
time and not listening to staff directives. Staff 1 recalled the youth
were unplugging individual cameras from their respective outlets
all over the house. Staff 1 stated he began to record the youth on
his personal cell phone in order to capture video because he knew
the security cameras would not be working in time. Staff 1
commented that he was trained at a previous facility to always
hold line of sight, and this included recording from a cell phone if
needed. Staff 1 stated Staff 2 also instructed him to do so in the
moment. Staff 1 stated he deleted all the footage of this incident
afterwards but could not specifically state if he informed
management at the facility if it was all completely deleted. He
recalled the Licensee Designee had instructed him to send her
4

what he recorded, delete it and she would design a policy
regarding a situation like this if it were to occur in the future.
Staff 2 was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
02/23/2024. She recalled the incident in question and working
with Staff 1 that evening. Staff 2 stated the youth began to pull
plugs from electrical outlets for the security cameras both
downstairs and upstairs while they were escalated. Staff 2 stated
she tried plugging some of them back in but did not do that for all
of them. She believed they would not have captured much
because they take a few minutes to get back to operational status.
Staff 2 recalled discussing with Staff 1 how to proceed and
agreeing they would need video footage of the youth destroying
property in the facility, so Staff 1 began to record on his personal
cell phone. Staff 1 stated she was not sure what Staff 2 did with
that footage afterwards.
Youth C was interviewed over the phone on 06/06/2024. She
stated she was aware she was being recorded by Staff 1 during
the night in question. She knew this because she recalled asking
him why he had his phone out and he stated he was recording
because other youth had broken the security cameras. Youth C
denied having concern that Staff 1 recorded herself or any of the
other youth while they were changing or in any other way that
invaded their privacy.
Youth D was interviewed over the phone on 06/06/2024. Youth D
knew that Staff 1 was recording the activity of herself and the
other youth on the night in question but denied she was recorded
while changing her clothes.
Youth E was interviewed over the phone on 06/07/2024. Youth E
remembered Staff 1 recording herself and her peers while they
were dancing to music on the television. Youth E did not believe
she or anyone else was recorded while changing by Staff 1 or any
other staff while she was placed at the facility.
Youth F was interviewed over the phone on 06/07/2024. She
recalled being involved in the situation in question when Staff 1
recorded the youth from his personal cell phone. Youth F stated
she and the other youth placed decided to have a dance party
because one of them was moving out the next day, and Staff 1
and Staff 2 told them not to. She recalled seeing Staff 1 have his
phone out and Youth F asked him if he was recording, and he
replied he was. Youth F believed the security cameras might
have been unplugged but was not sure. Youth F stated she only
5

witnessed Staff 1 with his phone out and recording when the youth
were together dancing in the living room, and did not have
concern that she was recorded while changing or in any other
private setting.
MDHHS pre-disposition meeting stated their investigation would
not produce any findings.
Documents reviewed:
• Video recordings from Staff 1’s personal cell phone was
provided. This recording occurred during the late evening of
12/24/2023. They depict a variety of activities of the youth
placed in the program as of that date, including dancing to
music on the television, breaking in to the staff office and
attempting to get access to case files, and eating food out
of the refrigerator. A youth can be heard in the background
referencing changing their clothes, but at no point did
anyone change their clothes during the footage.
Analysis Through interviews with staff and documentation reviewed there
was evidence found that the confidentiality of youth placed in the
program was broken due to Staff 1 recording them with his
personal phone.
Consultation provided:
• While it is a positive to have staff members working at the
facility who have worked in similar Child Caring Institution
settings, the program is advised to have clear discussions
at the hire of new employees and in trainings about
program specific policies and staff member’s need to avoid
using specific direction or procedure from past work
experiences.
• Staff members are encouraged to refrain from using
vocabulary such as “hissy fit” when describing the
behaviors of youth, as opposed to more trauma-informed
vocabulary.
Conclusion Violation Established
6

Rule Code Personal hygiene
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4148
Section (1) An institution shall assure that each resident maintains or
Description receives personal care, hygiene, and grooming appropriate to
the resident’s age, sex, race, cultural background, and health
needs.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Toilet paper and towels are not sufficiently provided to youth.
Investigation The Complainant was interviewed on 02/26/2024.
The facility was toured on unannounced visits on 01/30/2024 and
02/20/2024 and an announced visit on 02/29/2024. During each
visit all bathrooms and storage areas were checked for provisions
such as toilet paper, hand towels and shower towels. At no point
did the facility lack a reasonable amount of these provisions.
Email communication was received from DHHS Foster Care
Caseworker 1 on 02/26/2024. She stated there was a time when
she and a co-worker, DHHS Foster Care Caseworker 2, visited
the facility on 01/25/2024. She stated DHHS Foster Care
Caseworker 2 used the bathroom while at the facility and
accidentally dropped a roll of toilet paper in the toilet. DHHS
Foster Care Caseworker 1 asked a staff member who she could
not recall if there was any more toilet paper that could be used,
and the staff member stated she could not find any in the storage.
DHHS Foster Care Caseworker 1 stated this staff member
suggested that kitchen paper towel could be used.
Communication with DHHS Foster Care Caseworker 2 did not
occur as of the writing of this report.
Youth A and Youth B were interviewed separately during an
announced visit to the facility on 02/29/2024. They both made
similar statements regarding the program having sufficient items
such as toilet paper and towels.
Analysis Through interviews with youth and caseworkers as well as
multiple on-site visits there was not sufficient evidence found that
there has been a lack of towels or toilet paper in the facility.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
7

Rule Code Facility and premises maintenance
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4407
Section (3) The facility, including main and accessory structures, shall be
Description maintained so as to prevent and eliminate rodent and insect
harborage.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation There are rodents located within the walls of the building.
Investigation The Licensee Designee was interviewed during an
unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility on 01/30/2024. She
stated she has never seen issues with rodents or insects in the
facility. The Licensee Designee reported having pest control
services come to the facility periodically to provide preventative
services.
The facility was toured on unannounced visits on 01/30/2024 and
02/20/2024 and an announced visit on 02/29/2024. During each
visit all bathrooms, cabinets and storage areas were checked for
any evidence of rodent or insect presence. It was common for
insect or mouse traps to be seen in hard to reach areas, but no
concerns were noted at each visit.
Youth A and Youth B were interviewed separately during an
announced visit to the facility on 02/29/2024. Youth A and Youth
B stated they have not seen any insects or rodents within the
facility. They both recognized some of the traps that were located
in corners of cabinets and behind toilets, but neither youth took
issue with their presence.
A service provider for Orkin Pest Control was interviewed on
03/07/2024 during an announced, face-to-face visit at the facility.
The service provider confirmed they were present at the facility
that day to perform regular services. He stated he had been the
technician that had worked with the facility for pest control and
management for the past six months or so. He reported no
concerns and confirmed the service was being performed in a
preventative manner. The service provider stated the worst he
had seen of any pests or rodents in the facility were some spiders
that had been caught in traps in the basement and bathroom
areas where it would be expected that they might exist.
Documents reviewed:
• Documentation was provided for pest control services
being provided to the facility by Orkin Pest Control. Service
has been provided to the facility as recent as 10/23/2023
8

and 11/03/2023 with no concerns noted other than small
amounts of insects caught in a trap and then replaced by
the service provider.
Analysis Through interviews with youth and staff along with documentation
reviewed there was not sufficient evidence found that there has
been any verifiable concerns of rodent or insect infestation in the
facility.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Based on the findings in this report a CAP is required.
Per SIR #2024C0001037SI, a 1st provisional license is recommended.

sir_summary.summary: The investigation found two substantiated violations at the House of Love Agency: first, the Chief Administrator instructed a youth not to say anything that could get the facility shut down or get her in trouble, which constitutes obstructing an investigation; second, a staff member improperly recorded youth on his personal cell phone, violating confidentiality. The allegations regarding insufficient hygiene supplies and rodent infestation were not substantiated. The agency's leadership, particularly the Chief Administrator, bears clear responsibility for the substantiated violations regarding interference with an investigation.
